Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Starbucks "took Christ and Christmas off their brand new cups," implying that Starbucks intentionally removed these words.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence provided to support the assertion that Starbucks intentionally removed the words Christ and Christmas from their cups.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the absence of the words Christ and Christmas on Starbucks cups is a deliberate attempt to remove religious references.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided, stating that Starbucks has never included the words Christ or Christmas on their holiday cups in the first place.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Starbucks sells gift cards that say "Merry Christmas," indicating that the word Christmas is not banned at Starbucks.
Understate: The claim understates the fact that Starbucks has never included the words Christ or Christmas on their cups, as evidenced by a search of previous cup designs.
